details.description: If you've received too much money in benefits, how to query an overpayment, when you have to pay the money back and how you do this (eg through a payment plan)
details.body:
If you’ve been paid too much in benefits, you should tell the office dealing with your payment straightaway.

When you should contact the office

Contact the office if:

  • you think you’ve been overpaid
  • you get a letter telling you that you’ve been overpaid - the letter will tell you who to contact
  • your circumstances change and this is likely to affect a benefit

It’s your responsibility to tell the relevant office if your circumstances change or if you think you’re being overpaid - otherwise you could be prosecuted for benefit fraud.

When you have to repay the money

You’ll have to pay the money back if the overpayment was your fault, eg:

  • the information you gave was wrong
  • you didn’t report a change in your circumstances
  • there was an administrative mistake but you should have noticed the overpayment - for example, if you receive 2 payments instead of 1

If your landlord gets your Housing Benefit directly

Your landlord may be asked to repay the money if they’re responsible for the overpayment.

If the overpayment was your fault, you may have to repay it.

What happens if you’ve been overpaid

You’ll get a letter to let you know that you’ve overpaid. You should contact the office dealing with your benefit within 1 month if you think this is a mistake and you want to appeal the decision.

Making repayments

If you’re still receiving the benefit, the regular amount you get will be reduced until you’ve paid back the money.

Otherwise you’ll receive a bill. Contact the relevant office if you want to set up a payment plan.
